title: Kenichi Uemura
text:
is a former <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He played for the <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Uemura was born in <a href="Yatsushiro%2C%20Kumamoto">Yatsushiro</a> on April 22, 1974. After graduating from Matsunaga High School, he joined <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a> side <a href="Sanfrecce%20Hiroshima">Sanfrecce Hiroshima</a> in 1993. He broke into the first team in the first season. His first league appearance came on July 4, 1993 against <a href="Tokyo%20Verdy">Verdy Kawasaki</a> at <a href="Kawasaki%20Todoroki%20Stadium">Kawasaki Todoroki Stadium</a>. He scored his first professional goal on July 24, 1993 against <a href="Urawa%20Reds">Urawa Reds</a> at <a href="Coca-Cola%20West%20Hiroshima%20Stadium">Hiroshima Stadium</a>. He played in many matches as defender from his first season, except at times when he was injured.
After 11 year's long service at <a href="Sanfrecce%20Hiroshima">Sanfrecce Hiroshima</a>, he moved to <a href="Cerezo%20Osaka">Cerezo Osaka</a> in 2004, then <a href="Tokyo%20Verdy">Tokyo Verdy</a> (2005–2006). After a brief spell at <a href="YSCC%20Yokohama">YSCC Yokohama</a>, he joined <a href="Roasso%20Kumamoto">Rosso Kumamoto</a> (later "Roasso Kumamoto") in 2007. He damaged his knee ligaments three times and experienced seven operations. These injuries have affected his form. Uemura retired from professional football after the 2008 season.
National team career.
He represented the <a href="Japan%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Japan U-23 national team</a> at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201996%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">1996 Summer Olympics</a>. He played in 2 matches. He scored a goal in a group stage match against <a href="Hungary%20national%20football%20team">Hungary</a>. Although Japan won 2 matches, Japan exited in the first round. Japan beat <a href="Brazil%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Brazil</a> in their first game. It was known as the "Miracle of Miami" () in Japan.
In April 2001, Uemura was selected by the <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>. National team manager <a href="Philippe%20Troussier">Philippe Troussier</a> gave him his first full international cap on April 25 in a friendly against <a href="Spain%20national%20football%20team">Spain</a> in <a href="C%C3%B3rdoba%2C%20Spain">Córdoba</a>. He was a member of the Japan team for the <a href="2001%20FIFA%20Confederations%20Cup">2001 Confederations Cup</a>. He played three games and Japan won second place. He played 4 games for Japan in 2001.
Coaching career.
After the retirement, Uemura started coaching career at <a href="J2%20League">J2 League</a> club <a href="Roasso%20Kumamoto">Roasso Kumamoto</a> in 2009. In 2013, he moved to J2 club <a href="Kamatamare%20Sanuki">Kamatamare Sanuki</a> and served as coach under manager <a href="Makoto%20Kitano">Makoto Kitano</a>. However the club was relegated to <a href="J3%20League">J3 League</a> end of 2018 season. In 2019, Uemura became a manager as Kitano successor.
Managerial statistics.
Update; "December 31, 2018"
